journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Nonlinear free vibration analysis of annular sector plates using differential quadrature method

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shahid Bahonar University of Kerman, Kerman, Iran
2Department of Engineering Science and Mechanics, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shahid Bahonar University of Kerman, Kerman, Iran. email: saidi@mail.uk.ac.ir

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: The nonlinear free vibration of isotropic annular sector plates is studied using differential quadrature method. The geometric nonlinearity is used into the strains and based on the first-order shear deformation plate theory, the nonlinear governing equations of motion are obtained. According to differential quadrature analogue, the equations of motion and boundary conditions are discretized. The harmonic balance method is used to obtain the eigenvalue system. The eigenvalue system is solved using an iterative solution. The obtained results are verified for fully clamped annular sector plates and the convergence of results is investigated for some boundary conditions. The effects of some parameters, such as thickness to outer radius ratio, inner to outer radius ratio and sector angle on the nonlinear to linear natural frequency ratio, are also studied. It is shown that the simply supported plate is more sensitive to the geometrical parameters than the fully clamped plate.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The plates are the resistant structures which have been used extensively in industry. The linear vibration analysis of plates has been studied by many researchers. However, they might be subjected to some working conditions that indicate a nonlinear behaviour. Therefore, the nonlinear analysis of plates can be important for various industries. Huang and Zheng [1] studied nonlinear vibration and dynamic response of simply supported shear deformable laminated plates on elastic foundations using Reddy's higher-order shear deformation plate theory and general von Kármán-type equation, which includes the plate-foundation interaction. Leung and Zhu [2] introduced a trapezoidal hierarchical finite element for nonlinear free and forced vibration analyses of skew and trapezoidal Mindlin plates. Also, they considered clamped condition on the boundaries and weak nonlinearity without bifurcation. Huang and Shen [3] used the higher-order shear deformation plate theory and general von Kármán-type equation to investigate nonlinear free and forced vibration of simply supported shear deformable laminated plates with piezoelectric actuators. Chen [4] presented the nonlinear partial differential equations of nonlinear vibration for a functionally graded plate in a general state of non-uniform initial stress. Chien and Chen [5] studied the effects of initial stresses on the nonlinear vibrations of laminated plates resting on elastic foundations. Eshmatov [6] used the Kirchhoff–Love hypothesis and Reissner–Mindlin generalized theory to study the analyses of the nonlinear vibrations and dynamic stability of viscoelastic orthotropic plates. Singha and Daripa [7] investigated the large amplitude free flexural vibration behaviour of symmetrically laminated composite skew plates using the finite element method. Amabili and Farhadi [8] explored the nonlinear forced vibrations of isotropic and laminate composite rectangular plates by comparing the obtained results from classical, first-order and third-order shear deformation theories.

To solve the nonlinear vibration of plates for various boundary conditions, some numerical methods have been used. A common numerical method, which has been extensively used, is the differential quadrature method (DQM). This method was introduced by Bellman and Casti [9]. Liew and Liu [10] used DQM to analyze the free vibration of thick annular sector plates. Mirtalaie and Hajabasi [11] studied the free vibration analysis of functionally graded thin annular sector plates using the differential quadrature method. Bert et al. [12] used DQM to analyze nonlinear bending of isotropic and orthotropic rectangular plates. Li and Cheng [13] studied the nonlinear vibration of orthotropic rectangular plates based on Reddy's higher-order shear deformation theory using DQM. Malekzadeh [14, 15] investigated large amplitude free vibration of laminated skew thin plates and tapered Mindlin rectangular plates using DQM.

There are few studies in nonlinear vibration of annular sector plate plates in the literature. Only, for the special case of fully clamped annular sector plate, Houmat [16] studied the large amplitude free vibration of shear deformable laminated composite annular sector plate using sector p-element. To the best of the authors' knowledge, the nonlinear vibration analysis of annular sector plates under various boundary conditions has not been investigated yet.

In this paper, based on the first-order shear deformation plate theory, the nonlinear governing equations of motion of annular sector plates are obtained. As DQM gives a rapid convergence and accurate results in comparison with other numerical solutions in these typical problems [14], the method is used to solve the nonlinear equations. Using the harmonic balance method, an eigenvalue system is obtained. An iterative solution is used to solve the eigenvalue problem. After verifying the results for fully clamped annular sector plate, the convergence of the method is studied and the nonlinear to linear natural frequency ratio is given for both thick annular sector plate with immovable boundary conditions and thin annular sector plate with various boundary conditions. The obtained results for various boundary conditions can be used as benchmark. The effects of some parameters, such as thickness to radius ratio, inner to outer radius ratio and sector angle on the nonlinear to linear natural frequency ratio of annular sector plate with different boundary conditions, are discussed.

sec.title: 2 GOVERNING EQUATIONS
sec.p:
Consider an annular sector plate with the inner radius b, the outer radius a, thickness h and the sector angle α which is illustrated in Fig. 1. Based on the first-order shear deformable plate theory, the displacement field for such plate can be defined as follows (1a)
(1b)
(1c)

The geometric properties of annular sector plate

Considering the von Kármán theory for moderately large deflection, the strains can be declared at an arbitrary point in the plate as (2a)
(2b)

To obtain the equations of motion and related boundary conditions of the annular sector plate, the Hamilton's principle is used as follows (3) where the strain energy is given as (4)
σijs are the stress components (i and j =r, θ and z). Also, the kinetic energy is defined as (5)

Substituting equation (2) into equation (4) and using the variation of equations (4) and (5) into the Hamilton's principle (3), the equations of motion can be easily obtained as (6a)
(6b)

where I1, I2 and I3 are the inertia terms which are defined as (7)
The bending and twisting moments Mrr, Mθθ and Mrθ are (8)
Also, the in-plane forces Nrr, Nθθ and Nrθ are described as (9)
And the shear forces Qr and Qθ are defined as (10) where κ is the shear correction factor and in this study it is assumed to be π2/12.

It should be noted that the inertia term I2 vanishes for the isotropic materials by assuming middle plane as the reference plane. Using equations (6a) and (6b), the equation (6c) can be rewritten as follows (11)
The boundary conditions along the edges of the annular sector plate are expressed as:
Clamped: (12a)

Free: (12c)
In this study, the material properties follow the linear elasticity theory. According to the plane stress state, the stress components σij can be written as follows (13)

Substituting equations (8)–(10) into equations (6) and (11) and using equations (2) and (13), the governing equations can be obtained as (14a)

sec.title: 3 DQ-DISCRETIZATION
sec.p: To develop the DQ analogue, the sector plate should be discretized into a set of grid points. The DQM is based on the approximation of the partial derivative of a function with respect to a variable by a weighted linear combination of function variables at the grid points. The mth derivatives of the function f(r, θ) at the point (ri , θj) with respect to r and θ are approximated, respectively, as (16)

The weighting coefficients for the first-order derivative can be expressed in the form (17a)
(17b)
In the above equations, X = R, when x = r and X = θ, when x = θ and (18)

Also, the weighting coefficients for the higher-order derivatives are given as (19a)
(19b)

The Gauss–Lobatto–Chebyshev is a convenient relationship for the location choice of grid points in the engineering problems which is extensively used in the literature [15, 17, 18]. Based on this relationship, the grid points are concentrated close to the boundaries and it gives more accurate results. The location relationships of grid points for the annular sector plate in r and θ directions, respectively, are expressed as (20a)
(20b)

As the in-plane displacements of the middle plane u and v are much smaller than the transverse displacement w, the in-plane inertias can be neglected [19]. This case is valid only for thin plates, and it does not depend on the boundary condition of the plate. The reported results for annular circular plate with free edge based on classical plate theory and neglecting the in-plane accelerations have a good agreement with the experiments [20, 21]. But, the in-plane displacements are not negligible for moderate thick plates unless the edges of the plate are immovable. Therefore, the numerical results for annular sector plates with free boundary conditions are valid only for thin plates. By neglecting the in-plane accelerations, the governing equations of motion (14) can be discretized using equation (16) for i = 2, ...,, NR − 1 and j = 2, ...,, Nθ − 1, as (21a)
(21b)
(21c)
(21d)
(21e) where the index ij shows the value of the function in the specific grid point (ri, θj). In a similar manner, the in-plane boundary conditions are discretized as

p.italic: For clamped and simply supported edges:

sec.p: Also, the discretized forms of the out-of-plane boundary conditions are as follows
At the corner nodes, the following boundary conditions are used for immovable boundary conditions as: (24)
The immovable boundary condition is considered at the corner nodes for the mixture of movable and immovable boundary conditions.

The in-plane boundary conditions (22) can be arranged in the following matrix form (25) where the vector {fs(w2)} is a quadratic form of transverse displacement (s = 1 - 3). The in-plane degrees of freedom vectors in the domain and boundary grid points can be expressed, respectively, as (26a)
(26b) where N′R=NR–1 and N′Θ=NΘ–1. The first two discretized governing equations, (21a) and (21b), can be written in a matrix form as follows (27)
The boundary degrees of freedom vector is obtained from equation (25) as (28)
Substituting equation (28) into equation (27) yields the domain in-plane vector in the form (29)
where (30)

By substituting equation (29) into equation (28), the boundary in-plane degrees of freedom can be obtained. The in-plane forces can be found in terms of the transverse displacement by eliminating the in-plane displacements as follows (31) where the vector {N(w2)} is a quadratic form of the transverse displacement.

To solve the nonlinear vibration problems of the plates, an iterative procedure is used [14]. Using equation (31) into equation (21c), the last three equations of motion (21c), (21d) and (21e) can be written in the matrix form as (32) where [KI(w)] involves the nonlinear terms in the equation (21c) and [KBmn] and [KImn] are the linear stiffness matrixes (m, n = 1 - 3). The rotation and the transverse degrees of freedom vectors at the domain and the boundary grid points are shown, respectively, as (33a)
(33b)

The out-of-plane boundary conditions (23) can be easily shown in the following matrix forms (34a)
(34b) where [BB] = − [B2 ]−1[B1]. The matrix [BB] can be rewritten in a block matrix as follows (35) where [BBij] are blocks. To eliminate the boundary degrees of freedom vector, equation (34b) is substituted into equation (32). This procedure gives the eigenvalue matrix equations as (36)
where (37)

The harmonic balance method is used for the nonlinear flexural vibration analysis of the sector plate. Based on this method, it is assumed that the system has a harmonic motion. Since the nonlinearity of the plates is cubic, the odd harmonics has to be used [19, 20]. Therefore, the degrees of freedom of the plate are considered in the following forms (38)
Using equations (36) and (38), the nonlinear eigenvalue system can be written as (39)
Using the harmonic balance method in the equation of motion (21c) and eliminating higher-order approximations, the following relation can be obtained (40)

In the iterate procedure, the linear problem is solved firstly by vanishing the nonlinear terms in the matrix [KI(w)]. Substituting the eigenvector of the linear problem into the in-plane forces, the nonlinear coefficients [KI(w)] can be obtained. The nonlinear eigenvalue system (39) is solved again and the nonlinear eigenvector is obtained. The iterative procedure continues until two frequencies obtained from subsequent iterations satisfy the following relationship (41)

sec.title: 4 NUMERICAL RESULTS
sec.p:
In the present results, the Poisson's ratio υ is assumed to be 0.3. The boundary conditions of the plate are shown in capital letters like FCSC where F, C and S stand for free, clamped and simply support, respectively. Different combinations of free, simply supported and clamped boundary conditions are used on inner and outer circular edge and straight edges. The convergence of the nonlinear to linear fundamental frequency ratio for fully clamped edges with the inner to outer radius ratio b/a = 0.5, the thickness to outer radius ratio h/a = 0.005 and the sector angle α = 90° is shown in Table 1. The number of nodes is equal in all directions. The results have been compared with the results presented by Houmat [16] using the p-element method. In the low amplitude to thickness ratio wmax/h, the rate of convergency is rapid and the accurate results can be obtained with 11*11 grid points but for higher amplitude to thickness ratios, the number of grid points should be increased. Table 1.
Convergence of the nonlinear to linear frequency ratio for all clamped edges with b/a = 0.5, h/a = 0.005 and α = 90°

wmax⁡ h

0.8 1.1189 1.1198 1.1197 1.1197 1.1191
1 1.1835 1.1847 1.1846 1.1846 1.1837

Table 2 illustrates the convergence study of the nonlinear to linear fundamental frequency ratio for a fully simply supported plate. The inner to outer radius ratio and the sector angle have been taken as b/a = 0.5 and α = 90°, respectively. Also, two thickness to outer radius ratios h/a = 0.005 and 0.1 has been considered. The convergent rate of the fully simply supported annular sector plate is the same as fully clamped one. Table 2.

The effects of variation of the plate properties on the hardening behaviour of the fully simply supported annular sector plate are illustrated on the backbone curves for the first and second modes in r-direction. The nonlinear to linear frequency ratio is considered as a function of the maximum amplitude vibration to thickness ratio. The hardening effects on the first mode of fully clamped annular sector plate were studied (see e.g. [16]), and it was shown that the hardening behaviour exhibits a very small increase as α, b/a and h/a are increased.

Figure 2 shows the variation of the backbone curves with respect to the various thicknesses to outer radius ratios in the first and second modes for the annular sector plate with fully simply supported edges. It can be seen that the hardening effect of the sector plate enhances with increase of thickness to outer radius ratio in the first and second modes. The transverse displacement in the second mode is less than the first one. Thus, according to Fig. 2, the slope of the first mode curve is less than the second one. Figure 2
The backbone curves of fully simply supported annular sector plate with b/a = 0.5 and α = 90° in the first and second modes

The variation of the inner to outer radius ratio effect on the hardening behaviour of the fully simply supported annular sector plate is considered for the first and second modes in Fig. 3. It can be seen that the hardening effect of the sector plate increases with increase of inner to outer radii ratio in both first and second modes. Figure 3
The backbone curves of fully simply supported annular sector plate with h/a = 0.005 and α = 90° in the first and second modes

The backbone curves of the fully simply supported annular sector plate with various sector angles in the first and second modes are depicted in Fig. 4. It can be found that the hardening effect increases as the sector angle increases. Figure 4
The backbone curves of fully simply supported annular sector plate with h/a = 0.005 and b/a = 0.5 in the first and second modes

According to the obtained results from Figs. 2–4, it can be concluded that the variation of the second mode is more considerable than the first one. Therefore, the hardening effect varies in the second mode more significantly. In addition, it can be seen the variation of the hardening behaviour with the geometric properties in the second mode is higher than the first mode, which is expected. Also, by comparing these figures with the results of clamped annular sector plate [16], it can be seen that the changes of hardening behaviours with respect to geometric parameters for simply supported plates are more significant than the clamped ones.

Figure 5 is constructed to show the effect of geometric parameters on the hardening behaviour for a sector plate under SSCS boundary conditions. It is clear that when the inner to outer radius ratio increases, the variation of the hardening effect is more significant in comparison with the fully simply supported annular sector plate. But, this variation is not significant with increasing of the thickness to outer radius ratio and the sector angle. Figure 5
The comparative backbone curves of annular sector plate under SSCS boundary conditions with (a) b/a = 0.5> and α = 90°; (b) h/a = 0.1 and α = 90° and (c) h/a = 0.1 and b/a = 0.5

The nonlinear to linear fundamental frequency ratio for the thick annular sector plate with various combinations of clamped and simply supported boundary conditions in a range of the maximum amplitude to thickness ratios is given in Table 3. The geometrical properties are considered for thin and thick plates with two sector angles 60 and 90 degrees and the inner to outer radius ratio b/a = 0.5. It can be seen that the nonlinear to linear fundamental frequency ratio increases with the increase of sector angles for various immovable boundary conditions. Table 3.

The effect of free boundary condition on the hardening behaviour is investigated in Fig. 6. They show backbone curves for thin annular sector plate under some boundary conditions containing free edge. It can be seen that unlike the plates with immovable boundary conditions (Table 3), the hardening effect decreases with increasing of sector angle for annular sector plates with at least one free edge. Figure 6
The backbone curves of annular sector plate with h/a = 0.005 and b/a = 0.5 under some boundary conditions (a) CCFC; (b) FCFC and (c) FCSC

Table 4 shows the nonlinear to linear fundamental frequency ratio versus of the maximum amplitude to thickness ratio for thin annular sector plate under some boundary conditions containing free edge. The results are given for the annular sector plates with b/a = 0.5, h/a = 0.005 and two sector angles 120 and 135 degrees. The obtained results confirm the consequence, which is obtained from Fig. 6. sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
In this study, DQM has been used for nonlinear vibration analysis of annular sector plates. The governing equations of motion were obtained by considering first-order shear deformation plate theory. The in-plane inertias were neglected for both thick annular sector plate with immovable boundary conditions and thin annular sector plate with various boundary conditions. Based on DQ analogue, the governing equations of motion and boundary conditions were discretized. The equations of motion were described by harmonic motion and using the harmonic balance method which resulted in an eigenvalue system of equations. An iterative solution was used to solve the eigenvalue system and the nonlinear frequencies of the annular sector plate were calculated. A good agreement was found for the results of fully clamped edges with the results obtained using p-element method. The rapid convergence of the fundamental nonlinear to linear frequency ratio was seen. The geometric properties effects on the hardening behaviour of the simply supported annular sector plate in the first and second modes were investigated. As some consequences, the following results have been obtained:
The hardening effect for the simply supported annular sector plate in comparison with the clamped one varies more significantly.
The hardening effect increases with the increase of sector angles in various immovable boundary conditions.
The hardening effect decreases with increase of sector angle for annular sector plates containing free inner or outer edge, but it increases for annular sector plates containing immovable edges.
The variation of the hardening effect with respect to the geometric properties in the second mode is more than the first mode.
